bioghist.p: Theophilus Mills Taylor (1909-1989) was born in Cedarville, Ohio. He studied architecture at the University of Pennsylvania and worked as a teacher and architect in India for several years before studying theology at Pittsburgh-Xenia Theological Seminary. He graduated in 1941, was ordained and became assistant pastor of the First Presbyterian Church in Crafton, Pennsylvania. He then became pastor of the Barnet Center United Presbyterian Church in Barnet, Vermont. In 1943 he became a professor of New Testament literature and exegesis at Pittsburgh Theological Seminary. In 1956 he received a Ph.D. at Yale University. From 1958 to 1962, Dr. Taylor served as chairman of the Commission on Ecumenical Mission and Relations. In 1958, while presiding officer of his church, Taylor endorsed the use of ''troops and tanks, if necessary'' to enforce school integration in the South. He also criticized Governor Orval E. Faubus of Arkansas for closing four high schools in Little Rock rather than have them integrated. Taylor served as moderator of the General Assembly from 1958 to 1959. He later took a position as secretary of the General Assembly Mission Council, serving from 1962 to 1972.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers of Theophilus Mills Taylor. Papers related to the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the United States of America (NCC) include: memoranda; reports; studies; policy statements; newsletters; pamphlets; and a very small amount of Taylor's incoming and outgoing correspondence related to scheduling and other routine matters. Many of the papers are from the General Committee, the General Administration and Finance Committee. The collection also includes papers from various other committees and divisions of the NCC. Materials related to the World Council of Churches (WCC) include: minutes; memoranda; reports; proposals; summaries; agendas budgets; directories; a small amount of correspondence; and printed materials. Much of the material is related to the Division of Study and includes records of the Commission on Faith and Order and the Study of the Holy Eucharist. Other WCC materials relate to various Assemblies.
